   IMPRESSION:

   IMPRESSION:
   1. Areas of low attenuation in the periventricular and subcortical
   white
   matter, likely consistent with chronic small vessel ischemic changes.
   2. Possible lytic area noted at the anterior edge of C1, partially
   evaluated
   on the current scan. Likely degenerative cyst. Correlate with MRI of
   [**2109-10-31**].
   3. No acute intracranial process.

   [**11-1**] urine Cx pending, BCx pending x2

 ATRIAL FIBRILLATION (AFIB)
 RESPIRATORY FAILURE, ACUTE (NOT ARDS/[**Doctor Last Name **])
 [**Last Name 121**] PROBLEM - ENTER DESCRIPTION IN COMMENTS

 GAIT, IMPAIRED
 AEROBIC CAPACITY / ENDURANCE, IMPAIRED
 BALANCE, IMPAIRED
 KNOWLEDGE, IMPAIRED
 .H/O CHRONIC OBSTRUCTIVE PULMONARY DISEASE (COPD, BRONCHITIS,
   EMPHYSEMA) WITH ACUTE EXACERBATION
 UPPER EXTREMITY FRACTURE (SHOULDER, HUMERAL, RADIAL, ULNAR, HAND)
   Assessment and Plan: 89 year old male with a history of COPD,
   hypertension, chronic kidney disease, hypertension and end stage
   congestive heart failure who was found down in his living [**Apartment Address(1) **] days
   prior to admission found to have odontoid and right wrist fractures now
   transferred from TSICU for hypoxic and hypercarbic respiratory failure.
   Hypoxic and Hypercarbic Respiratory Failure:  Pt with h/o HF and COPD,
   so likely mutifactorial. Lasix and Lisinopril were held and the pt was
   receiving IVF
s which could have tipped him over towards pulmonary
   edema although imaging doesn
t fully support this. Requires 2L O2 at
   baseline. Also seen to have bilateral opacifications at the bases.
   - Continue with Levofloxacin for CAP, today is day [**1-31**]
   - Follow speciation of initial 1+ GNR
s on sputum Cx
   - lasix 40 mg IV BID as blood pressure will tolerate
   - Captopril was held yesterday for low bp. If bp can tolerate through
   today, would add it back for afterload reduction.
   - Metoprolol 25 mg PO BID for heart failure
   - albuterol and ipratropium nebulizers for potential obstructive
   component
   - Pressure support has been weaned from 10
 5 and pt is oxygenating
   well
   - CO2
s continue to be in the high 50
s, which may be were pt lives
   chronically with h/o COPD.
   - SBT today with plans to wean and hopefully extubated
   - Will need scheduled nebs after extubation.
   Tachycardia: Sepsis vs volume depletion vs anemia with falling Hct vs
   didn
t get beta blockade on the floor. Volume depletion less likely as
   pt with good bp, has been net positive through yesterday and was not
   getting Lasix on the floor. Could be evolving septic picture as pt with
   low grade temps over yesterday and h/o temp to 102 recently. BCx
   negative to date.
   - Metoprolol 25 mg PO BID
   - Watch BCx
s and continue Levofloxacin for now, if appears to be
   getting more septic, broaden coverage
   Hypotension: Patient transiently hypotensive in the setting of
   receiving large doses of metoprolol, diltiazem, propofol and induction
   agents for intubation.  Then seen to have episode of hypotension after
   admission which has now resolved and pt is mildly hypertensive
   currently.
   - Have switched to Fentanyl Versed instead of Propofol for sedation
   - Consider small amts of fluids if hypotense with h/o CHF
   - follow blood cultures
   - Restarted on home dose of steroids
   Delerium: Unclear etiology.  Differential diagnosis includes
   medications, infection, metabolic abnormalities etc.  Urinalysis
   negative.  Blood cultures pending.  [**Month (only) 60**] have small pneumonia on xray.
   ABG intially with well compensated respiratory acidosis now with acute
   decompensation.  Morphine may be contributing.
   - Tylenol and Fentanyl for pain as needed
   - - follow blood and urine cultures
   - PRN zydis for agitation
   - Will try to wean sedation through today and see how his mental status
   is
   Right wrist fracture: Now reduced and casted.  No plans for operative
   intervention.
   - orthopedics followup
   Dens Fracture:  [**Last Name (un) 10782**] Type II dens fracture.  Non-operative.
   Currently in [**Location (un) 2420**] J Collar.
   - continue collar
   - will need orthopedics followup
   - Q4H neurologic checks
   Chronic Kidney Disease: Baseline creatinine 1.4-1.6.  Currently
   slightly worsened at 1.9 and rising.
   - Consider small amts of fluids, also if hypotensive, but need to be
   careful with h/o CHF
   - renally dose medications
   - trend creatinine
   Anemia: Baseline hematocrit in the high 30s, now in the high 20s.  No
   signs of acute blood loss currently.  Has trended down over the past 48
   hours.
   - active type and screen
 outdates [**2109-11-3**]
   - Guiac all stools
   - Trend Hct
 repeat this pm
   - iron deficient
 start PO iron through NGT and bowel regimen
   - Folate, B12 normal
   - Iron studies more consistent with ACD
   - trend hematocrit with transfusion goal < 21
   Hypertension: Transiently hypotensive in the setting of medications.
   Would likely benefit from resuming afterload reduction in the setting
   of severe MR/AR.
   - Can restart Captopril 12.5 mg TID if not having any more hypotension
   through today
   - Continue metoprolol 25 mg PO BID
   Congestive Heart Failure: Concern for exacerbation of end stage
   diastolic heart failure complicated by severe AR and moderate MR in the
   setting of IV fluid resuscitation and holding home medications.
   - lasix 40 mg IV BID
   - captopril 12.5 mg TID
   - resume metoprolol
   - I/O goal -1  liter today as bp can tolerate
   COPD: Unclear history.  Patient has a history of CO2 retention at
   baseline and uses home oxygen at 2L.  He does not take inhalers at home
   but has been prescribed them in the past.
   - albuterol and ipratropium nebulizers standing
   Gout:
   - continue home prednisone
   - holding allopurinol
   Benign Prostatic Hypertrophy:
   - holding agents while has foley in place
   FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes, tube feeds
    Prophylaxis: Subutaneous heparin. Will start PPI today.
    Access: femoral line (will remove if hemodynamically stable after
   extubation and not requiring central access), arterial line
    Code:  Full (discussed with son)
    Communication: Patient,  son [**Name (NI) 3080**] [**Name (NI) **] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 10783**]
   Disposition: pending clinical improvement
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:
   Arterial Line - [**2109-11-1**] 06:54 PM
   Multi Lumen - [**2109-11-1**] 08:49 PM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT:
   Stress ulcer:
   VAP:
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments:
   Code status: DNR / DNI
   Disposition:
   ------ Protected Section ------
   I saw & examined the pt & was physically present with the ICU team for
   the key portions of services provided. I agree w/Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 10784**]
s note
   above, including assessment and plan. I would add:
   89 yo male admitted for wrist and odontoid fracture. Course complicated
   by hypercarbic and hypoxic respiratory failure requiring intubation
   with TSICU-->MICU transfer [**11-1**]. Suspect inciting factor of pulmonary
   edema from skipped diuretics +/- PNA with poor reserve from
   pre-existing COPD/CHF
   24 hour events: transiently hypotensive in the context of beta-blocker
   +propofol+ captopril. Received 250cc bolus with improvt
   Rx: Lopressor
   pepcid
   Hep, LVQ, alb, SSI
   Bolus fentanyl and versed for sedation
   Exam
   I/O 1.5 liter positive
   Vent: PSV 5/5 FiO2 30; ABG 7.35/53/86
   Intubated
   [**Location (un) 2420**] J collar
   Lungs: fair air movement
   CV: sys murmur at apex, diastolic [**1-30**] at USB
   Abd +bs, soft nontender
   Ext: no edema
   WBC 9, Hct 26 (30, 2 days ago)
   Bun/Cr 35/1.9
   Imp:
   89 yo male with valvular HD/COPD /chronic aspiration admitted with
   odontoid fracture and wrist fracture; course c/b hypercarbic
   respiratory failure
   1. acute Resp failure:
   Doing well on SBT, though remain concerned that pulmonary edema could
   be an issue once extubated
   lasix 40 mg IV now then goal fluid balance negative 1 liters\; Check
   BNP
   Will move to extubate
   Continue LVQ for LLL infiltrate; Change alb/atrovent inhalers to
   scheduled nebs
   2. HTN: BP meds held due to hypotension (sedation +meds)- will
   introduce back into regimen gradually
   3. AMS: Reportedly more combative on the floor, though currently not
   requiring much sedation. Will re-assess once pt extubated, re-orient
   pt, family at bedside, assess pain
   4. wrist and odontoid fracture: No surgical intervention planned-
   5. Anemia: Hct lower today, no obvious bleeding. Will guiac stools,
   trend hct's
   Rest of plan per ICU team
   Pt is crit. Ill. Total time spent: 40 min.
   ------ Protected Section Addendum Entered By:[**Name (NI) 749**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) **], MD
   on:[**2109-11-3**] 14:05 ------

Based on the patient's progress note, the following potential medical complications can arise:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient has acute respiratory failure, and the note mentions concerns about pulmonary edema, which could worsen respiratory function. Monitoring for signs of respiratory distress, such as tachypnea, tachycardia, and decreased oxygen saturation, is crucial.
2. Hypotension: The patient has experienced transient hypotension, which can lead to organ dysfunction and increased mortality. Monitoring for signs of hypotension, such as decreased blood pressure, tachycardia, and decreased urine output, is essential.
3. Sepsis: The patient's temperature has been elevated, and there is a concern about evolving septicemia. Monitoring for signs of sepsis, such as tachycardia, tachypnea, and increased white blood cell count, is crucial.
4. Anemia: The patient's hemoglobin level is decreasing, which can lead to anemia. Monitoring for signs of anemia, such as fatigue, shortness of breath, and pale skin, is essential.
5. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's stool guaiac test is positive, which suggests gastrointestinal bleeding. Monitoring for signs of bleeding, such as melena, hematochezia, and decreased hemoglobin level, is crucial.
6. Cardiac complications: The patient has a history of congestive heart failure, and the note mentions concerns about exacerbation of end-stage diastolic heart failure. Monitoring for signs of cardiac complications, such as increased jugular venous distension, rales, and decreased cardiac output, is essential.
7. Pneumonia: The patient's chest X-ray shows bilateral opacifications at the bases, which could indicate pneumonia. Monitoring for signs of pneumonia, such as fever, cough, and increased white blood cell count, is crucial.
8. Fluid overload: The patient has received large amounts of fluids, which can lead to fluid overload. Monitoring for signs of fluid overload, such as increased jugular venous distension, rales, and decreased urine output, is essential.
9. Wrist and odontoid fracture complications: The patient's wrist and odontoid fractures could lead to complications, such as infection, nonunion, or malunion. Monitoring for signs of fracture complications, such as increased pain, swelling, and decreased range of motion, is crucial.
10. Delirium: The patient's mental status is altered, and the note mentions concerns about delirium. Monitoring for signs of delirium, such as confusion, agitation, and disorientation, is essential.

To mitigate these potential complications, the patient should be closely monitored for signs of respiratory distress, hypotension, sepsis, anemia, gastrointestinal bleeding, cardiac complications, pneumonia, fluid overload, wrist and odontoid fracture complications, and delirium.

   prior to admission found to have odontoid and right wrist fractures now
   transferred from TSICU for hypoxic and hypercarbic respiratory failure.
   Hypoxic and Hypercarbic Respiratory Failure:  Pt with h/o HF and COPD,
   so likely mutifactorial. Lasix and Lisinopril were held and the pt was
   receiving IVF
s which could have tipped him over towards pulmonary
   edema although imaging doesn
t fully support this. Requires 2L O2 at
   baseline. Also seen to have bilateral opacifications at the bases.
   - Continue with Levofloxacin for CAP, today is day [**1-31**]
   - Follow speciation of initial 1+ GNR
s on sputum Cx
   - lasix 40 mg IV BID as blood pressure will tolerate
   - Captopril was held yesterday for low bp. If bp can tolerate through
   today, would add it back for afterload reduction.
   - Metoprolol 25 mg PO BID for heart failure
   - albuterol and ipratropium nebulizers for potential obstructive
   component
   - Pressure support has been weaned from 10
 5 and pt is oxygenating
   well
   - CO2
s continue to be in the high 50
s, which may be were pt lives
   chronically with h/o COPD.
   - SBT today with plans to wean and hopefully extubate
   Tachycardia: Sepsis vs volume depletion vs anemia with falling Hct vs
   didn
t get beta blockade on the floor. Volume depletion less likely as
   pt with good bp, has been net positive through yesterday and was not
   getting Lasix on the floor. Could be evolving septic picture as pt with
   low grade temps over yesterday and h/o temp to 102 recently. BCx
   negative to date.
   - Metoprolol 25 mg PO BID
   - Watch BCx
s and continue Levofloxacin for now, if appears to be
   getting more septic, broaden coverage
   Hypotension: Patient transiently hypotensive in the setting of
   receiving large doses of metoprolol, diltiazem, propofol and induction
   agents for intubation.  Then seen to have episode of hypotension after
   admission which has now resolved and pt is mildly hypertensive
   currently.
   - Have switched to Fentanyl Versed instead of Propofol for sedation
   - Consider small amts of fluids if hypotense with h/o CHF
   - follow blood cultures
   - Restarted on home dose of steroids
   Delerium: Unclear etiology.  Differential diagnosis includes
   medications, infection, metabolic abnormalities etc.  Urinalysis
   negative.  Blood cultures pending.  [**Month (only) 60**] have small pneumonia on xray.
   ABG intially with well compensated respiratory acidosis now with acute
   decompensation.  Morphine may be contributing.
   - Tylenol and Fentanyl for pain as needed
   - - follow blood and urine cultures
   - PRN zydis for agitation
   - Will try to wean sedation through today and see how his mental status
   is
   Right wrist fracture: Now reduced and casted.  No plans for operative
   intervention.
   - orthopedics followup
   Dens Fracture:  [**Last Name (un) 10782**] Type II dens fracture.  Non-operative.
   Currently in [**Location (un) 2420**] J Collar.
   - continue collar
   - will need orthopedics followup
   - Q4H neurologic checks

   - Consider small amts of fluids, also if hypotensive, but need to be
   careful with h/o CHF
   - renally dose medications
   - trend creatinine
   Anemia: Baseline hematocrit in the high 30s, now in the high 20s.  No
   signs of acute blood loss currently.  Has trended down over the past 48
   hours.
   - active type and screen

   - iron deficient
 start PO iron through NGT and bowel regimen

   - Continue metoprolol 25 mg PO BID

Summary:

The patient is an 89-year-old male with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), hypertension, chronic kidney disease, and end-stage congestive heart failure. He was found unresponsive at home and was admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) with hypoxic and hypercarbic respiratory failure. The patient has been diagnosed with atrial fibrillation, respiratory failure, and impaired transfers. He has a right wrist fracture and a dens fracture, both of which are being treated conservatively.

Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient has acute respiratory failure with a need for mechanical ventilation. His oxygenation is improving, but his carbon dioxide levels remain high.
2. Hypotension: The patient has had episodes of hypotension, which have been treated with fluids and vasopressors.
3. Tachycardia: The patient's heart rate is elevated, which may be due to sepsis, volume depletion, or anemia.
4. Anemia: The patient's hematocrit is low, and he is being treated with iron supplements and blood transfusions.
5. Chronic Kidney Disease: The patient's creatinine levels are elevated, and he is at risk for further kidney damage.
6. Congestive Heart Failure: The patient has end-stage congestive heart failure, which is exacerbated by his acute respiratory failure.
7. COPD: The patient has chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, which is contributing to his respiratory failure.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Pneumonia: The patient has bilateral opacifications at the bases of his lungs, which may indicate pneumonia.
2. Sepsis: The patient's elevated white blood cell count and low-grade fever suggest the possibility of sepsis.
3. Pulmonary Embolism: The patient's history of chronic kidney disease and immobility make him at risk for pulmonary embolism.
4. Gastrointestinal Bleeding: The patient's history of chronic kidney disease and use of anticoagulants make him at risk for gastrointestinal bleeding.
5. Wound Infection: The patient's right wrist fracture and dens fracture are at risk for wound infection.

Plan:

1. Continue mechanical ventilation and oxygen therapy to improve the patient's oxygenation and ventilation.
2. Monitor the patient's blood pressure and adjust his vasopressor therapy as needed.
3. Treat the patient's anemia with iron supplements and blood transfusions.
4. Continue his antibiotics for pneumonia and sepsis.
5. Monitor the patient's kidney function and adjust his fluid management accordingly.
6. Continue his medications for congestive heart failure and COPD.
7. Monitor the patient's wound healing and adjust his treatment plan as needed.

Based on the provided physician's daily progress note, the patient is a critically ill individual with multiple comorbidities, including atrial fibrillation, respiratory failure, impaired transfers, gait, aerobic capacity, and balance. The patient has a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), bronchitis, and emphysema, which has led to an acute exacerbation.

The patient is currently intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation with a CPAP/PSV mode, with a set tidal volume of 500 mL and a spontaneous tidal volume of 476 mL. The patient's oxygen saturation is 95% on 30% FiO2, and their ABG results show a pH of 7.34, PaO2 of 367, and PaCO2 of 57.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, decreased hemoglobin, and increased creatinine levels. The patient's troponin-T level is 0.02, indicating possible myocardial injury.

Imaging studies, including a CT chest and CT head, show bilateral opacification at the lung bases, concerning for aspiration, pneumonia, or atelectasis. The CT head also shows areas of low attenuation in the periventricular and subcortical white matter, likely consistent with chronic small vessel ischemic changes.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is critical, and further deterioration could lead to respiratory arrest.
2. Pneumonia: The patient's bilateral opacification at the lung bases on the CT chest scan is concerning for pneumonia, which could worsen their respiratory status.
3. Atrial fibrillation: The patient's atrial fibrillation could lead to decreased cardiac output and further compromise their respiratory status.
4. Myocardial injury: The patient's elevated troponin-T level suggests possible myocardial injury, which could worsen their cardiac function.
5. Sepsis: The patient's elevated white blood cell count and possible pneumonia could lead to sepsis, which could further complicate their condition.
6. Renal dysfunction: The patient's increased creatinine levels could indicate renal dysfunction, which could worsen their overall condition.
7. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's impaired balance and gait could lead to falls, which could result in gastrointestinal bleeding.

Based on the patient's condition, it is essential to closely monitor their respiratory status, cardiac function, and renal function. The patient should be managed with aggressive respiratory therapy, including mechanical ventilation and oxygen therapy, to maintain adequate oxygenation and ventilation. The patient's cardiac function should be monitored closely, and consideration should be given to anti-coagulation therapy to prevent thrombus formation. Renal function should be closely monitored, and consideration should be given to dialysis if necessary. The patient's gastrointestinal status should also be closely monitored, and consideration should be given to prophylactic measures to prevent gastrointestinal bleeding.

   admission which has now resolved and pt is mildly hypertensive
   currently.

   - follow blood cultures

   negative.  Blood cultures pending.  [**Month (only) 60**] have small pneumonia on xray.

   careful with h/o CHF
   - renally dose medications
   - trend creatinine

   signs of acute blood loss currently.  Has trended down over the past 48
   hours.

 repeat this pm

 start PO iron through NGT and bowel regimen

   - trend hematocrit with transfusion goal < 21

   - Continue metoprolol 25 mg PO BID

Summary:

The patient is a 89-year-old male with a history of COPD, hypertension, chronic kidney disease, and end-stage congestive heart failure who was admitted to the ICU for hypoxic and hypercarbic respiratory failure. He has a bilateral opacification at the lung bases, concerning for aspiration, pneumonia, or atelectasis. He also has a small right pleural effusion and a stable ascending aortic aneurysm. He has a history of chronic kidney disease with a baseline creatinine of 1.4-1.6, which has worsened to 1.9 and rising. He has anemia with a hematocrit in the high 20s, and iron deficiency. He has a history of hypertension, which is currently being managed with metoprolol and lasix. He has a history of COPD, which is exacerbating his respiratory failure.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure is likely to worsen if he does not receive adequate oxygen therapy and mechanical ventilation.
2. Pneumonia: The bilateral opacification at the lung bases may be due to aspiration, pneumonia, or atelectasis, which could lead to further respiratory failure and sepsis.
3. Sepsis: The patient's low-grade fever and elevated white blood cell count suggest that he may be developing sepsis, which could lead to multi-organ dysfunction.
4. Cardiac Complications: The patient's history of congestive heart failure and end-stage diastolic heart failure makes him prone to cardiac complications, such as cardiac arrhythmias, cardiac failure, and cardiogenic shock.
5. Renal Failure: The patient's worsening renal function and anemia may lead to acute kidney injury or chronic kidney disease, which could require dialysis.
6. Gastrointestinal Complications: The patient's history of chronic kidney disease and anemia may lead to gastrointestinal complications, such as constipation, diarrhea, or bleeding.
7. Neurological Complications: The patient's history of hypertension and chronic kidney disease may lead to neurological complications, such as stroke, seizures, or cognitive impairment.

Recommendations:

1. Continue oxygen therapy and mechanical ventilation to manage the patient's respiratory failure.
2. Administer antibiotics to treat possible pneumonia or sepsis.
3. Manage the patient's cardiac condition with medications such as metoprolol and lasix.
4. Monitor the patient's renal function and adjust medications accordingly.
5. Monitor the patient's gastrointestinal function and adjust medications accordingly.
6. Monitor the patient's neurological function and adjust medications accordingly.
7. Consider consult with cardiology, nephrology, and pulmonology to optimize the patient's care.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 89-year-old male with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), hypertension, chronic kidney disease, and end-stage congestive heart failure. He was found down in his living room and was transferred to the intensive care unit (ICU) for hypoxic and hypercarbic respiratory failure.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: The patient's respiratory status has improved with diuresis and on room air. His sats vary widely depending on whether he is clearing his secretions, but typically improve with suctioning.
* Cardiovascular: The patient has atrial fibrillation and is at risk for congestive heart failure exacerbation. His blood pressure is elevated, and his heart rate is tachycardic.
* Renal: The patient's creatinine level is slightly worsened at 1.8, and he has a history of chronic kidney disease.
* Hematological: The patient has anemia of chronic disease, and his hematocrit has trended down over the past 48 hours.
* Neurological: The patient has a dens fracture and is currently in a collar. He also has a history of chronic kidney disease and hypertension.

The patient's medical complications include:

* Respiratory failure
* Atrial fibrillation
* Congestive heart failure
* Chronic kidney disease
* Anemia
* Dens fracture

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Levofloxacin for community-acquired pneumonia
* Lasix for congestive heart failure
* Metoprolol for tachycardia and hypertension
* Albuterol and ipratropium nebulizers for potential obstructive component
* Titration of O2 as needed to maintain sats
* Captopril hold due to risk of hypotension
* Increase in metoprolol to 25 mg PO QID
* Tylenol for pain
* Low-dose fentanyl as needed for pain
* Follow-up blood and urine cultures
* PRN zydis for agitation
* Encourage OOB

The patient's disposition is pending clinical improvement, likely to floor tomorrow.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Respiratory failure exacerbation
* Congestive heart failure exacerbation
* Chronic kidney disease worsening
* Anemia worsening
* Dens fracture complications
* Gout flare-up
* Benign prostatic hypertrophy complications

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust the plan of care as needed to prevent or manage these potential complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 89-year-old male with a history of COPD, hypertension, chronic kidney disease, hypertension, and end-stage congestive heart failure. He was found down in his living room and was transferred to the ICU for hypoxic and hypercarbic respiratory failure.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory status: The patient is on room air and has improved significantly, with a pCO2 of around 60s. He has been extubated and is receiving captopril 6.25mg daily.
* Cardiovascular status: The patient has atrial fibrillation and is experiencing tachycardia, which is unclear in etiology. His blood pressure is stable, and he has been started on metoprolol 25mg PO BID.
* Renal status: The patient has chronic kidney disease, and his creatinine has worsened to 1.8. He is receiving lasix 40mg IV BID and captopril 12.5mg TID.
* Hematological status: The patient has anemia, with a hematocrit in the high 20s. He is receiving iron studies, B12, folate, hemolysis labs, and reticulocyte count.
* Neurological status: The patient has delirium, which is unclear in etiology. He is receiving tylenol for pain and low-dose fentanyl as needed.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status can deteriorate if he develops pneumonia or other respiratory infections.
* Cardiac complications: The patient's atrial fibrillation and tachycardia can lead to cardiac complications such as heart failure, arrhythmias, or even cardiac arrest.
* Renal complications: The patient's chronic kidney disease can worsen if he develops acute kidney injury or if his medications are not adjusted properly.
* Anemia: The patient's anemia can worsen if he develops bleeding or if his medications are not adjusted properly.
* Delirium: The patient's delirium can worsen if he develops infections or if his medications are not adjusted properly.

In conclusion, the patient is a complex case with multiple comorbidities, and close monitoring and management are necessary to prevent potential medical complications.

Based on the physician's daily progress note, I summarize the patient's condition as follows:

The patient is a 89-year-old male with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), hypertension, chronic kidney disease, hypertension, and end-stage congestive heart failure. He was found down in his living apartment days prior to admission and was transferred from the surgical intensive care unit (TSICU) to the intensive care unit (ICU) due to hypoxic and hypercarbic respiratory failure.

The patient's current condition is characterized by:

1. Hypoxic and Hypercarbic Respiratory Failure: Primarily caused by acute on chronic diastolic heart failure worsened by hypertension and tachycardia.
2. Tachycardia: Unclear etiology, possibly related to mild volume overload or mild infection.
3. Electrolyte and Fluid Disorder: Altered mental status, atrial fibrillation, and respiratory failure.
4. Chronic Kidney Disease: Baseline creatinine 1.4-1.6, currently slightly worsened at 1.8.
5. Anemia: Baseline hematocrit in the high 30s, now in the high 20s, likely anemia of chronic disease.
6. Congestive Heart Failure: Concern for exacerbation of end-stage diastolic heart failure complicated by severe AR and moderate MR.
7. COPD: Unclear history, patient has a history of CO2 retention at baseline and uses home oxygen at 2L.
8. Gout: Patient has a history of gout, currently holding allopurinol.
9. Benign Prostatic Hypertrophy: Patient has a history of benign prostatic hypertrophy, currently holding agents while has foley in place.

Potential medical complications that can arise from these conditions include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure can worsen, leading to acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), pneumonia, or respiratory arrest.
2. Cardiac complications: The patient's congestive heart failure can exacerbate, leading to cardiac arrest, cardiogenic shock, or arrhythmias.
3. Kidney complications: The patient's chronic kidney disease can worsen, leading to acute kidney injury, chronic kidney disease progression, or end-stage renal disease.
4. Anemia: The patient's anemia can worsen, leading to fatigue, shortness of breath, or decreased cognitive function.
5. Gout: The patient's gout can flare up, leading to joint pain, swelling, and limited mobility.
6. Benign Prostatic Hypertrophy: The patient's benign prostatic hypertrophy can worsen, leading to urinary retention, urinary tract infections, or bladder stones.

Based on the patient's condition, the physician's plan includes:

1. Diuresis to manage fluid overload and heart failure.
2. Medication adjustments to manage hypertension, tachycardia, and respiratory failure.
3. O2 therapy to maintain sats.
4. Nebulizers for potential obstructive component.
5. Active type and screen for blood transfusion.
6. Trending creatinine to monitor kidney function.
7. Monitoring for signs of acute blood loss.
8. Holding home medications and restarting diuresis.
9. Continuing prophylaxis for DVT, stress ulcer, and VAP.

The patient's disposition is pending clinical improvement, likely to be transferred to the floor tomorrow.

   Assessment and Plan: 89 year old male with a history of COPD,
   hypertension, chronic kidney disease, hypertension and end stage
   congestive heart failure who was found down in his living [**Apartment Address(1) **] days
   prior to admission found to have odontoid and right wrist fractures now
   transferred from TSICU for hypoxic and hypercarbic respiratory failure.
   #) Hypoxic and Hypercarbic Respiratory Failure:  put out about 400ccs
   to lasix dose yesterday, will need more than that
   Primarily caused by acute on chronic diastolic heart failure worsened
   by hypertension and tachycardia.  Improved with diuresis and on room
   air, as home sats are likely in the low 90s and similar.  His sats vary
   widely depending on if he is clearing his secretions, but typically
   improve with suctioning.  On levofloxacin day [**3-31**] today for CAP, given
   750mg PO QOD.  We will restart diuresis as heart failure is playing a
   large role.
   - levofloxacin 750 mg PO every other day for community acquired
   pneumonia w/ renal failure
   - follow up sputum cultures
   - lasix 40 mg IV once, f/u I/O
s and PM lytes to reassess need for
   second dose.
   - increase metoprolol to 25 mg PO QID to help tachycardia and HTN.
   - albuterol and ipratropium nebulizers for potential obstructive
   component
   - titrate O2 as needed to maintain sats.
   #) Tachycardia:  Unclear etiology.  EKGs consistent with sinus
   tachycardia with frequent PACs. [**Month (only) 60**] be related to mild volume overload
   versus mild infection.  Given concern for congestive heart failure will
   resume patient's home beta blocker and diurese.
   - metoprolol 25 mg PO QID
   #) s/p femoral line site bleed: Unclear why he had such a severe bleed
   after removal of a venous line with a normal INR and normal platelets.
   Received 1U PRBC with an appropriate bump.  Appears to have been an
   isolated event.
   #) Delerium: Was delirius with an unclear etiology.  Differential
   diagnosis includes medications, infection, metabolic abnormalities
   etc.  Urinalysis negative.  Blood cultures pending.  This has improved,
   and he seems to do best with his family at the bedside.
   - tylenol for pain
   - low dose fentanyl as needed for pain
   - follow blood and urine cultures
   - PRN zydis for agitation
   - Encourage OOB.
   #) Right wrist fracture: Now reduced and casted.  No plans for
   operative intervention.
   - orthopedics followup
   #) Dens Fracture:  [**Last Name (un) 10782**] Type II dens fracture.  Non-operative.
   Currently in [**Location (un) 2420**] J Collar.
   - continue collar
   - will need orthopedics followup
   - Q4H neurologic checks
   #) Chronic Kidney Disease: Baseline creatinine 1.4-1.6.  Currently
   slightly worsened at 1.8.
   - renally dose medications
   - trend creatinine
   - titrate diuresis to avoid large rise in creatinine.
   #) Anemia: Baseline hematocrit in the high 30s, now in the high 20s.
   No signs of acute blood loss currently.  Has trended down over the past
   48 hours.  Appears on labs to be anemia of chronic disease.
   - active type and screen
   - trend hematocrit with transfusion goal < 21
   #) Congestive Heart Failure: Concern for exacerbation of end stage
   diastolic heart failure complicated by severe AR and moderate MR in the
   setting of IV fluid resuscitation and holding home medications.
   - lasix 40 mg IV once, then follow-up
   - stop captopril
   - metoprolol 25mg QID
   - I/O goal - 1 liter today
   #) COPD: Unclear history.  Patient has a history of CO2 retention at
   baseline and uses home oxygen at 2L.  He does not take inhalers at home
   but has been prescribed them in the past.
   - albuterol and ipratropium nebulizers standing
   #) Gout:
   - continue home prednisone
   - holding allopurinol
   #) Benign Prostatic Hypertrophy:
   - holding agents while has foley in place
   FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes, tube feeds

Summary:

The patient is an 89-year-old male with a history of COPD, hypertension, chronic kidney disease, and end-stage congestive heart failure, who was admitted with hypoxic and hypercarbic respiratory failure. He has multiple comorbidities, including atrial fibrillation, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), chronic kidney disease, and end-stage congestive heart failure. He has a recent history of odontoid and right wrist fractures.

The patient's current condition is characterized by:

* Hypoxic and hypercarbic respiratory failure, primarily caused by acute on chronic diastolic heart failure worsened by hypertension and tachycardia.
* Tachycardia, unclear etiology, with frequent PACs.
* Right wrist fracture, now reduced and casted, with no plans for operative intervention.
* Dens fracture, type II, non-operative, with a collar in place.
* Chronic kidney disease, with a baseline creatinine of 1.4-1.6 and currently worsened at 1.8.
* Anemia, likely anemia of chronic disease, with a trend downward over the past 48 hours.
* Congestive heart failure, with concern for exacerbation of end-stage diastolic heart failure complicated by severe AR and moderate MR.
* COPD, with unclear history, and a history of CO2 retention at baseline and using home oxygen at 2L.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen due to his underlying COPD, chronic kidney disease, and congestive heart failure.
2. Heart failure: The patient's congestive heart failure may exacerbate due to his chronic kidney disease, hypertension, and tachycardia.
3. Kidney disease: The patient's chronic kidney disease may worsen due to his congestive heart failure, hypertension, and tachycardia.
4. Anemia: The patient's anemia may worsen due to his chronic kidney disease, congestive heart failure, and ongoing bleeding.
5. Infection: The patient's recent history of odontoid and right wrist fractures may increase his risk of infection, particularly pneumonia.
6. Bleeding: The patient's recent bleeding from his femoral line site may indicate a bleeding disorder or a problem with his coagulation cascade.
7. Delirium: The patient's delirium may worsen due to his underlying medical conditions, medications, and sleep deprivation.
8. Gout: The patient's gout may flare up due to his chronic kidney disease, congestive heart failure, and hypertension.
9. Benign prostatic hypertrophy: The patient's benign prostatic hypertrophy may worsen due to his congestive heart failure, hypertension, and chronic kidney disease.

Assessment and Plan:

The patient's care plan includes:

* Managing his respiratory failure with oxygen therapy, nebulizers, and diuresis.
* Managing his heart failure with diuresis, metoprolol, and lasix.
* Managing his chronic kidney disease with renally dosed medications, trend creatinine, and titrate diuresis.
* Managing his anemia with active type and screen, trend hematocrit, and transfusion goal < 21.
* Managing his COPD with albuterol and ipratropium nebulizers.
* Managing his gout with continued home prednisone and holding allopurinol.
* Managing his benign prostatic hypertrophy by holding agents while the patient has a foley in place.

The patient will require close monitoring of his vital signs, laboratory results, and medication regimen to prevent complications and optimize his care.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 89-year-old male with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), hypertension, chronic kidney disease, hypertension, and end-stage congestive heart failure. He was found down in his living room and was transferred to the ICU for hypoxic and hypercarbic respiratory failure.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory status: The patient is on 30% FiO2 with a shovel mask due to hypoxic and hypercarbic respiratory failure. His oxygen saturation varies widely, but typically improves with suctioning.
* Electrolyte and fluid disorder: The patient has hypernatremia likely due to diuresis and slight hypovolemia. He is being given 1L of free water and his electrolytes will be monitored.
* Delirium: The patient has been persistently delirious with an unclear etiology. A possible pneumonia is being considered, and he is being treated with Tylenol and low-dose fentanyl as needed for pain.
* Tachycardia: The patient's tachycardia is unclear in etiology, but he is being treated with metoprolol 25mg PO QID to reduce afterload.
* Right wrist fracture: The patient has a type II dens fracture that is being treated non-operatively with a collar.
* Chronic kidney disease: The patient's creatinine is slightly worse at 1.8, and he is being treated with renally dosed medications and monitored for trends.
* Anemia: The patient has anemia of chronic disease, and he is being treated with active type and screen and transfusion goal < 21.
* Congestive heart failure: The patient has concern for exacerbation of end-stage diastolic heart failure complicated by severe AR and moderate MR. He is being treated with lasix 40mg IV once, metoprolol 25mg QID, and I/O goal - 1 liter today.
* COPD: The patient has a history of CO2 retention at baseline and uses home oxygen at 2L. He is being treated with albuterol and ipratropium nebulizers standing.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is critical, and he is at risk of further respiratory failure if his oxygen saturation drops or he experiences increased respiratory distress.
* Cardiac failure: The patient has concern for exacerbation of end-stage diastolic heart failure complicated by severe AR and moderate MR, which can lead to further cardiac failure.
* Infection: The patient has a possible pneumonia and is being treated with antibiotics, but he is at risk of developing further infections if his immune system is compromised.
* Electrolyte imbalance: The patient has hypernatremia and is at risk of developing further electrolyte imbalances if his electrolytes are not closely monitored.
* Delirium: The patient's delirium is unclear in etiology, and he is at risk of developing further delirium if his underlying condition is not treated.
* Tachycardia: The patient's tachycardia is unclear in etiology, and he is at risk of developing further tachycardia if his heart rate is not closely monitored.
* Anemia: The patient's anemia is chronic, but he is at risk of developing further anemia if his underlying condition is not treated.

Based on the patient's current condition and potential medical complications, it is recommended that he continue to be closely monitored in the ICU for any changes in his condition and that his treatment plan be adjusted as needed to address any emerging complications.

   tachycardia, though now his primary problem is his difficulty clearing
   secretions.  While his O2 sats are generally in the mid to high 90s, he
   has periodic drops to the 80s and is therefore being kept on 30% FiO2
   with shovel mask.  He is still requiring Q3hr or more frequent
   suctioning.  Switched from levofloxacin to azithro/ceftriaxone out of
   fear of worsening mental status, now day 2 of 7 days.  No organisms on
   sputum.
   - ceftriaxone 1 gm Q24, azithromycin 500mg Q24 today day 2 of 7.
   - goal fluid balance even today.  Given that he is already almost 1L
   positive, will give 40mg lasix x1.
   - keep metoprolol at 25 mg PO QID and restart captopril 6.25mg TID to
   reduce afterload.
   - continue albuterol and ipratropium nebulizers
   - titrate O2 as needed to maintain sats.
   #) Hypernatremia: Improved yesterday with 1L of D5W.  Today we will
   follow and give added free water if needed.
   - f/u PM lytes.
   #) Delerium: Has been persistently delirious with an unclear etiology.
   Differential diagnosis includes medications, infection, metabolic
   abnormalities etc.  Has had a possible pneumonia, urine negative, blood
   cx pending.  This has improved, and he seems to do best with his family
   at the bedside.
   - Tylenol first, then low dose fentanyl as needed for pain
   - repeat UA/culture and blood cultures.
   - PRN zydis for agitation
 has not been required to date.
   - Encourage OOB.
   #) Tachycardia:  Unclear etiology.  EKGs consistent with sinus
   tachycardia with frequent PACs and PVCs. We are trying to control with
   metoprolol QID.
   - metoprolol 25 mg PO QID
   #) Right wrist fracture: Now reduced and casted.  No plans for
   operative intervention.
   - orthopedics followup
   #) Dens Fracture:  [**Last Name (un) 10782**] Type II dens fracture.  Non-operative.
   Currently in [**Location (un) 2420**] J Collar.
   - continue collar.  Ask ortho how much longer that will be necessary.
   - will need orthopedics followup
   - Q4H neurologic checks
   #) Chronic Kidney Disease: Baseline creatinine 1.4-1.6.  Currently
   improved with creatinine 1.3 after receiving extra fluids yesterday.
   - renally dose medications
   - trend creatinine
   - goal today for I/Os is even to avoid further insult.
   #) Anemia: Baseline hematocrit in the high 30s, today 23.8.  Had large
   bleed several days ago from fem line site, none since.  Appears on labs
   to be anemia of chronic disease.
   - active type and screen
   - trend hematocrit with transfusion goal < 21
   #) Congestive Heart Failure: Concern for exacerbation of end stage
   diastolic heart failure complicated by severe AR and moderate MR in the
   setting of IV fluid resuscitation and holding home medications.
   - lasix 40 mg IV once, then follow-up
   - captopril 12.5mg TID and metoprolol 25mg QID
   - I/O goal
 even today
   #) COPD: Unclear history.  Patient has a history of CO2 retention at
   baseline and uses home oxygen at 2L.  He does not take inhalers at home
   but has been prescribed them in the past.  We are giving albuterol and
   ipratropium nebulizers standing
   #) Gout:  continue home prednisone
   #) Benign Prostatic Hypertrophy: holding agents while he has foley in
   place
   FEN: NG tube w/ tube feeds, replete electrolytes PRN
   Prophylaxis: Subutaneous heparin and pneumo boots.
   Access: PICC line and A-line
   Code:  Full (discussed with son)
   Communication: Patient,  son [**Name (NI) 3080**] [**Name (NI) **] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 10783**]
   Disposition: pending clinical improvement, likely to floor tomorrow.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 89-year-old male with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), hypertension, chronic kidney disease, aortic insufficiency, and congestive heart failure. He was found down in his living apartment days prior to admission and was transferred to the ICU for hypoxic and hypercarbic respiratory failure.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory status: He is still requiring Q3hr or more frequent suctioning, and his O2 sats are generally in the mid to high 90s but with periodic drops to the 80s. He is being kept on 30% FiO2 with a shovel mask.
* Electrolyte and fluid disorder: His sodium levels have improved, and he is still requiring fluid management to avoid further electrolyte imbalances.
* Altered mental status: The patient's mental status is persistently altered, with unclear etiology, and is being managed with Tylenol and low-dose fentanyl as needed for pain.
* Tachycardia: The patient's tachycardia is unclear etiology, and is being managed with metoprolol 25 mg PO QID.
* Right wrist fracture: The patient's wrist fracture is now reduced and casted, with no plans for operative intervention.
* Dens fracture: The patient has a type II dens fracture, which is being managed non-operatively with a collar.
* Chronic kidney disease: The patient's creatinine levels have improved, and he is being managed with renally-dosed medications.
* Anemia: The patient's anemia is being managed with active type and screen and transfusion goal < 21.
* Congestive heart failure: The patient is at risk for exacerbation of end-stage diastolic heart failure, and is being managed with lasix 40 mg IV once, followed by captopril 12.5mg TID and metoprolol 25mg QID.
* COPD: The patient has a history of CO2 retention and is being managed with albuterol and ipratropium nebulizers standing.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's current condition include:

* Pneumonia: The patient's persistently altered mental status and difficulty clearing secretions make him at risk for developing pneumonia.
* Sepsis: The patient's unclear etiology of altered mental status and his recent history of possible pneumonia make him at risk for developing sepsis.
* Respiratory failure: The patient's persistent requirement for Q3hr or more frequent suctioning and his periodic drops in O2 sats make him at risk for developing respiratory failure.
* Cardiac complications: The patient's history of congestive heart failure and his current management with lasix and captopril make him at risk for developing cardiac complications such as cardiac arrhythmias or heart failure exacerbation.
* Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's history of chronic kidney disease and his current management with electrolyte replacement make him at risk for developing gastrointestinal complications such as nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea.
* Neurological complications: The patient's persistently altered mental status and his recent history of possible pneumonia make him at risk for developing neurological complications such as seizures or stroke.

It is essential to continue monitoring the patient's condition closely and adjusting his management plan as needed to prevent or manage these potential complications.

   failure will resume patient's home beta blocker and diurese.

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 89-year-old male admitted to the ICU with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), hypertension, chronic kidney disease, aortic insufficiency, and congestive heart failure. The patient was found down in his living room and was transferred to the ICU for hypoxic and hypercarbic respiratory failure.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: The patient has persistent hypoxic and hypercarbic respiratory failure, requiring 30% FiO2 with a shovel mask and frequent suctioning.
* Cardiovascular: The patient has atrial fibrillation, tachycardia, and possible exacerbation of end-stage diastolic heart failure complicated by severe aortic regurgitation and moderate mitral regurgitation.
* Neurological: The patient has altered mental status, unclear etiology, with a possible diagnosis of delirium.
* Renal: The patient has chronic kidney disease with a baseline creatinine of 1.4-1.6, currently slightly worse at 1.8.
* Hematological: The patient has anemia of chronic disease with a trend down over the past 48 hours.
* Musculoskeletal: The patient has a right wrist fracture, reduced and casted, and a dens fracture, currently in a collar.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 14.3-14.4 K/uL
* Hemoglobin: 7.6-7.7 g/dL
* Platelet count: 251-272 K/uL
* Creatinine: 1.8-1.5 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen: 32-34 mg/dL
* Glucose: 121-154 mg/dL
* Calcium: 8.3-8.4 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 2.4-2.5 mg/dL
* Phosphate: 2.3-2.4 mg/dL

The patient's imaging results show:

* Chest X-ray: Increased left pleural effusion and retrocardiac opacity

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Respiratory: Continue O2 therapy, suctioning as needed, and nebulizers.
* Cardiovascular: Continue metoprolol and captopril, and titrate O2 as needed.
* Neurological: Continue delirium management, repeat UA/culture and blood cultures, and encourage OOB.
* Renal: Trend creatinine and goal fluid balance even.
* Hematological: Trend hematocrit with transfusion goal < 21.
* Musculoskeletal: Continue orthopedic follow-up and Q4H neurologic checks.

The patient's potential medical complications include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen if not managed properly.
* Cardiovascular complications: The patient's atrial fibrillation, tachycardia, and possible exacerbation of end-stage diastolic heart failure may lead to cardiovascular complications.
* Neurological complications: The patient's altered mental status and possible delirium may lead to neurological complications.
* Renal complications: The patient's chronic kidney disease may worsen if not managed properly.
* Hematological complications: The patient's anemia of chronic disease may worsen if not managed properly.
* Musculoskeletal complications: The patient's right wrist fracture and dens fracture may lead to musculoskeletal complications.

The patient's disposition is pending clinical improvement, likely to be transferred to the floor tomorrow.

   Assessment and Plan: 89 year old male with a history of COPD,
   hypertension, chronic kidney disease, aortic insufficiency and
   congestive heart failure who was found down in his living [**Apartment Address(1) **] days
   prior to admission.  Here he was found to have odontoid and right wrist
   fractures, transferred from TSICU for hypoxic and hypercarbic
   respiratory failure.  Here is stable with persistently altered mental
   status and difficulty clearing secretions.
   #) Hypoxic and Hypercarbic Respiratory Failure:  Initially caused by
   acute on chronic heart failure worsened by hypertension and
   tachycardia, though now his primary problem is his difficulty clearing
   secretions.  While his O2 sats are generally in the mid to high 90s, he
   has periodic drops to the 80s and is therefore being kept on 30% FiO2
   with shovel mask.  He is still requiring Q3hr or more frequent
   suctioning.  Switched from levofloxacin to azithro/ceftriaxone out of
   fear of worsening mental status, now day 2 of 7 days.  No organisms on
   sputum.
   - ceftriaxone 1 gm Q24, azithromycin 500mg Q24 today day 2 of 7.
   - goal fluid balance even today.  Given that he is already almost 1L
   positive, will give 40mg lasix x1.
   - keep metoprolol at 25 mg PO QID and restart captopril 6.25mg TID to
   reduce afterload.
   - continue albuterol and ipratropium nebulizers
   - titrate O2 as needed to maintain sats.
   #) Hypernatremia: Improved yesterday with 1L of D5W.  Today we will
   follow and give added free water if needed.
   - f/u PM lytes.
   #) Delerium: He continues to wax and wane quite a bit.  Yesterday
   afternoon, his sons thought he was improved, this morning on rounds he
   will not even open his eyes and mostly just withdraws from noxious
   stimuli and mumbles in Cantonese.  We have not found a clear infectious
   source, though ICU admission alone in a man with baseline dementia
   could explain his severe delirium.  We worry that we missed something
   that may have caused his initial fall.  We will consult neurology for
   their input in case we are missing some cause of his persistent altered
   mental status.
   - Neurology consult
   - MRI head w/ and w/o contrast, specifically to assess if he had a
   stroke at some point.
   - Tylenol first, then low dose fentanyl as needed for pain
   #) Tachycardia:  Unclear etiology.  EKGs consistent with sinus
   tachycardia with frequent PACs and PVCs. We are trying to control with
   metoprolol QID.
   - metoprolol 25 mg PO QID
   #) Right wrist fracture: Now reduced and casted.  No plans for
   operative intervention.
   - orthopedics followup
   #) Dens Fracture:  [**Last Name (un) 10782**] Type II dens fracture.  Non-operative.
   Currently in [**Location (un) 2420**] J Collar.
   - continue collar.  Ask ortho how much longer that will be necessary.
   - will need orthopedics followup
   - Q4H neurologic checks
   #) Chronic Kidney Disease: Baseline creatinine 1.4-1.6.  Currently
   improved with creatinine 1.3 after receiving extra fluids yesterday.
   - renally dose medications
   - trend creatinine
   - goal today for I/Os is even to avoid further insult.
   #) Anemia: Baseline hematocrit in the high 30s, today 23.8.  Had large
   bleed several days ago from fem line site, none since.  Appears on labs
   to be anemia of chronic disease.
   - active type and screen
   - trend hematocrit with transfusion goal < 21
   #) Congestive Heart Failure: Concern for exacerbation of end stage
   diastolic heart failure complicated by severe AR and moderate MR in the
   setting of IV fluid resuscitation and holding home medications.
   - lasix 40 mg IV once, then follow-up
   - captopril 12.5mg TID and metoprolol 25mg QID
   - I/O goal
 even today
   #) COPD: Unclear history.  Patient has a history of CO2 retention at
   baseline and uses home oxygen at 2L.  He does not take inhalers at home
   but has been prescribed them in the past.  We are giving albuterol and
   ipratropium nebulizers standing
   #) Gout:  continue home prednisone
   #) Benign Prostatic Hypertrophy: holding agents while he has foley in
   place
   FEN: NG tube w/ tube feeds, replete electrolytes PRN
   Prophylaxis: Subutaneous heparin and pneumo boots.

Summary:

The patient is an 89-year-old male admitted to the ICU with hypoxic and hypercarbic respiratory failure, altered mental status, atrial fibrillation, and multiple comorbidities. He has a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), hypertension, chronic kidney disease, aortic insufficiency, and congestive heart failure. He was found down in his living room and was transferred to the ICU for respiratory failure. He is currently stable but still requires oxygen therapy and suctioning. His mental status is altered, and he has difficulty clearing secretions.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's primary problem is his difficulty clearing secretions, which can lead to further respiratory failure if not managed properly.
2. Sepsis: The patient has a urinary tract infection (UTI) and may be at risk for developing sepsis.
3. Delirium: The patient's altered mental status may be due to delirium, which can be caused by a variety of factors, including infection, medication, and underlying medical conditions.
4. Tachycardia: The patient's tachycardia may be due to atrial fibrillation, hypertension, or other underlying medical conditions.
5. Anemia: The patient's anemia may be due to chronic disease or bleeding.
6. Hypernatremia: The patient's hypernatremia may be due to dehydration or excessive sodium intake.
7. Chronic Kidney Disease: The patient's chronic kidney disease may worsen if not managed properly.
8. Congestive Heart Failure: The patient's congestive heart failure may exacerbate if not managed properly.
9. Gastrointestinal Complications: The patient's NG tube and tube feeds may lead to gastrointestinal complications such as nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea.
10. Venous Thromboembolism (VTE): The patient's risk of developing VTE is increased due to his immobility and underlying medical conditions.

Recommendations:

1. Continue oxygen therapy and suctioning as needed to manage the patient's respiratory failure.
2. Monitor the patient's mental status and adjust his medications as needed to manage his delirium.
3. Manage the patient's tachycardia with metoprolol and monitor his response.
4. Monitor the patient's anemia and transfuse as needed to maintain a hematocrit of less than 21.
5. Monitor the patient's hypernatremia and adjust his fluids as needed to maintain a sodium level of less than 145 mmol/L.
6. Manage the patient's chronic kidney disease with renally adjusted medications and monitor his creatinine level.
7. Monitor the patient's congestive heart failure and adjust his medications as needed to manage his symptoms.
8. Monitor the patient's gastrointestinal symptoms and adjust his tube feeds as needed to prevent complications.
9. Monitor the patient's risk of VTE and adjust his prophylaxis as needed to prevent complications.

   Assessment and Plan: 89 year old male with a history of COPD,
   hypertension, chronic kidney disease, hypertension and end stage
   congestive heart failure who was found down in his living [**Apartment Address(1) **] days
   prior to admission found to have odontoid and right wrist fractures now
   transferred from TSICU for hypoxic and hypercarbic respiratory failure.
   #) Hypoxic and Hypercarbic Respiratory Failure:  Primarily caused by
   acute on chronic diastolic heart failure worsened by hypertension and
   tachycardia.  While his O2 sats are generally in the mid to high 90s,
   he has periodic drops to the 80s and is therefore being kept on 30%
   FiO2 with shovel mask.  His sats vary widely depending on if he is
   clearing his secretions, but typically improve with suctioning.  Has
   been on levofloxacin, which may be worsening his mental status.  We
   will switch to azithro/ceftriaxone instead, with a plan of 7 days.
   Sputum cultures showed just commensal flora.
   - ceftriaxone 1 gm Q24, azithromycin 500mg Q24 today day 1 of 7.
   - lasix 40 mg IV once, f/u I/O
s and PM lytes to reassess need for
   second dose.
   - keep metoprolol at 25 mg PO QID and restart captopril 6.25mg TID to
   reduce afterload.
   - albuterol and ipratropium nebulizers for potential obstructive
   component
   - titrate O2 as needed to maintain sats.
   - goal I/Os today even, so we will hold lasix for now.
   #) Hypernatremia: Likely due to diuresis and slight hypovolemia.  We
   will stop diuresing for now, give 1L of free water, and then monitor.
   - f/u PM lytes.
   #) Delerium: Has been persistently delirious with an unclear etiology.
   Differential diagnosis includes medications, infection, metabolic
   abnormalities etc.  Has had a possible pneumonia, urine negative, blood
   cx pending.  This has improved, and he seems to do best with his family
   at the bedside.
   - Tylenol first, then low dose fentanyl as needed for pain
   - repeat UA/culture and blood cultures.
   - PRN zydis for agitation
 has not been required to date.
   - Encourage OOB.
   #) Tachycardia:  Unclear etiology.  EKGs consistent with sinus
   tachycardia with frequent PACs. Given concern for congestive heart
   failure will resume patient's home beta blocker and diurese.
   - metoprolol 25 mg PO QID
   #) Right wrist fracture: Now reduced and casted.  No plans for
   operative intervention.
   - orthopedics followup
   #) Dens Fracture:  [**Last Name (un) 10782**] Type II dens fracture.  Non-operative.
   Currently in [**Location (un) 2420**] J Collar.
   - continue collar.  Ask ortho how much longer that will be necessary.
   - will need orthopedics followup
   - Q4H neurologic checks
   #) Chronic Kidney Disease: Baseline creatinine 1.4-1.6.  Currently
   slightly worse at 1.8.
   - renally dose medications
   - trend creatinine
   - goal today for I/Os is even to avoid further insult.
   #) Anemia: Baseline hematocrit in the high 30s, now in the high 20s.
   No signs of acute blood loss currently.  Has trended down over the past
   48 hours.  Appears on labs to be anemia of chronic disease.
   - active type and screen
   - trend hematocrit with transfusion goal < 21
   #) Congestive Heart Failure: Concern for exacerbation of end stage
   diastolic heart failure complicated by severe AR and moderate MR in the
   setting of IV fluid resuscitation and holding home medications.
   - lasix 40 mg IV once, then follow-up
   - stop captopril
   - metoprolol 25mg QID
   - I/O goal - 1 liter today
   #) COPD: Unclear history.  Patient has a history of CO2 retention at
   baseline and uses home oxygen at 2L.  He does not take inhalers at home
   but has been prescribed them in the past.
   - albuterol and ipratropium nebulizers standing
   #) Gout:
   - continue home prednisone
   - holding allopurinol
   #) Benign Prostatic Hypertrophy:
   - holding agents while has foley in place
   FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes, place NG tube for tube feeds
   Prophylaxis: Subutaneous heparin and pneumo boots.
   Access: multiple PIVs, arterial line

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 89-year-old male with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), hypertension, chronic kidney disease, and end-stage congestive heart failure. He was found down in his living room days prior to admission and was found to have odontoid and right wrist fractures. He was transferred from the surgical intensive care unit (TSICU) to the medical intensive care unit (ICU) for hypoxic and hypercarbic respiratory failure.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: Hypoxic and hypercarbic respiratory failure, primarily caused by acute on chronic diastolic heart failure worsened by hypertension and tachycardia. He is being kept on 30% FiO2 with a shovel mask.
* Electrolytes: Hypernatremia (Na 142 mmol/L) likely due to diuresis and slight hypovolemia. His potassium (K) levels are normal, but his calcium (Ca) levels are slightly low (8.3 mg/dL).
* Renal function: Chronic kidney disease with a baseline creatinine of 1.4-1.6 mmol/L, currently slightly worse at 1.8 mmol/L.
* Hematocrit: Anemia of chronic disease, with a baseline hematocrit in the high 30s, now in the high 20s.
* Cardiovascular: Concern for exacerbation of end-stage diastolic heart failure complicated by severe AR and moderate MR in the setting of IV fluid resuscitation and holding home medications.
* Infectious disease: Possible pneumonia, urine negative, blood cx pending. He has been persistently delirious with an unclear etiology.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's hypoxic and hypercarbic respiratory failure may worsen if not adequately managed.
2. Electrolyte imbalance: The patient's hypernatremia and possible hypokalemia may lead to cardiac arrhythmias, muscle weakness, and other complications.
3. Renal failure: The patient's chronic kidney disease may worsen if not managed properly, leading to acute kidney injury or chronic kidney disease progression.
4. Anemia: The patient's anemia of chronic disease may worsen if not managed properly, leading to decreased oxygen delivery to tissues and increased risk of cardiovascular complications.
5. Cardiovascular complications: The patient's concern for exacerbation of end-stage diastolic heart failure may lead to cardiovascular complications such as heart failure, arrhythmias, and cardiogenic shock.
6. Infectious disease: The patient's possible pneumonia and pending blood cultures may lead to sepsis, septic shock, and other complications.
7. Delirium: The patient's persistently delirious state may worsen if not managed properly, leading to increased risk of falls, pressure ulcers, and other complications.

The patient's plan of care includes:

1. Respiratory support: Continue oxygen therapy and suctioning as needed.
2. Electrolyte management: Monitor and manage electrolyte levels to prevent imbalance.
3. Renal function management: Monitor and manage renal function to prevent worsening of chronic kidney disease.
4. Anemia management: Monitor and manage anemia to prevent worsening of cardiovascular complications.
5. Cardiovascular management: Monitor and manage cardiovascular status to prevent exacerbation of end-stage diastolic heart failure.
6. Infectious disease management: Monitor and manage possible pneumonia and pending blood cultures to prevent sepsis and other complications.
7. Delirium management: Monitor and manage delirious state to prevent worsening of symptoms and complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 66-year-old male admitted to the ICU with a chief complaint of altered mental status. The patient has undergone various tests and procedures, including ultrasound, magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), and magnetic resonance angiography (MRA).

The patient's vital signs are as follows:

* Temperature: 37.7°C (99.8°F)
* Heart rate: 101 beats per minute (bpm)
* Blood pressure: 153/52 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 20 breaths per minute (bpm)
* Oxygen saturation: 95%
* White blood cell count: 14.3 x 10^9/L
* Hemoglobin: 7.5 g/dL
* Platelet count: 265 x 10^9/L

The patient has a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), bronchitis, and emphysema, with an acute exacerbation. He also has an upper extremity fracture (shoulder, humeral, radial, ulnar, and hand).

The patient's physical examination reveals:

* General appearance: Not interactive, does not respond to voice or tactile stimulation, but withdraws to light in the eyes
* Cardiovascular: Systolic and diastolic murmur
* Peripheral vascular: Right radial pulse not assessed, left radial pulse not assessed, right DP pulse not assessed, left DP pulse not assessed
* Respiratory/chest: Grossly rhonchorous upper airways with audible secretions
* Abdominal: Soft, non-tender
* Extremities: Right hand swollen, not tender to palpation, still has right PICC and right art line
* Skin: Not assessed
* Neurologic: Responds to: Not assessed, movement: Not assessed, tone: Not assessed

The patient's laboratory results show:

* Sodium: 141 mmol/L
* Potassium: 4.2 mmol/L
* Chloride: 104 mmol/L
* Bicarbonate: 32 mmol/L
* Glucose: 176 mg/dL
* Calcium: 7.9 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 2.2 mg/dL
* Phosphorus: 3.0 mg/dL
* White blood cell count: 14.3 x 10^9/L
* Hemoglobin: 7.5 g/dL
* Platelet count: 265 x 10^9/L
* Lactic acid: 1.3 mmol/L
* LDH: 196 IU/L
* Ca++: 7.9 mg/dL
* Mg++: 2.2 mg/dL
* PO4: 3.0 mg/dL

The patient's imaging studies show:

* MRI head without contrast: No significant abnormalities
* RUE u/s: No deep vein thrombosis (DVT)
* CXR: Increasing left pleural effusion and retrocardiac opacity, right lung remains clear

The patient's diagnosis includes:

* Electrolyte and fluid disorder
* Altered mental status (not delirium)
* Atrial fibrillation (AFIB)
* Respiratory failure, acute (not ARDS)
* Transfers, impaired
* Gait, impaired
* Aerobic capacity/endurance, impaired
* Balance, impaired
* Knowledge, impaired

The patient's plan includes:

* Recommendation for MRI brain with and without contrast (including diffusion images) rather than a CT scan
* Continue to correct any metabolic abnormalities, continue work-up and treatment of infection, and minimize sedatives
* Continue to monitor neurologic status for improvement and obtain neurologic baseline from family
* If patient spikes a new fever despite antibiotics, consider doing an LP in addition to the usual fever work-up
* Continue to follow with the neurology consultant

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

* Further deterioration of respiratory status
* Development of sepsis or septic shock
* Increased risk of bleeding due to coagulopathy
* Progression of encephalopathy to coma or brain death
* Development of cardiac arrhythmias or heart failure
* Increased risk of pressure ulcers due to immobility
* Development of respiratory failure requiring mechanical ventilation
* Increased risk of infection due to impaired immune function
* Development of electrolyte imbalances or acid-base disorders
* Progression of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) exacerbation to respiratory failure or death.

   Assessment and Plan: 89 year old male with a history of COPD,
   hypertension, chronic kidney disease, aortic insufficiency and
   congestive heart failure who was found down in his living [**Apartment Address(1) **] days
   prior to admission.  Here he was found to have odontoid and right wrist
   fractures, transferred from TSICU for hypoxic and hypercarbic
   respiratory failure.  Here he is stable from respiratory standpoint but
   active issues are now persistently altered mental status, difficulty
   clearing secretions, R hand swelling.
   #) Hypoxic and Hypercarbic Respiratory Failure:  Initially caused by
   acute on chronic heart failure worsened by hypertension and
   tachycardia, though now his primary problem is his difficulty clearing
   secretions.  While his O2 sats are generally in the mid to high 90s, he
   has periodic drops to the 80s and is therefore being kept on 30% FiO2
   with shovel mask.  He is still requiring Q3hr or more frequent
   suctioning.  Switched from levofloxacin to azithro/ceftriaxone out of
   fear of worsening mental status, now day 3 of 7 days.  No organisms on
   sputum.
   - ceftriaxone 1 gm Q24, azithromycin 500mg Q24 today day 3 of 7.
   - goal fluid balance even today.  Will give 40mg IV Lasix this am.
   - keep metoprolol at 25 mg PO QID and continue captopril 12.5mg TID to
   reduce afterload.
   - continue albuterol and ipratropium nebulizers
   - titrate O2 as needed to maintain sats.
   - continue frequent suctioning to clear secretions
   #) Delerium: He continues to wax and wane quite a bit.  He is able to
   communicate with his sons and they think he has improved, when we speak
   to him he doesn
t open his eyes and withdraws from noxious stimuli. We
   have not found a clear infectious source, though ICU admission alone in
   a man with baseline dementia could explain his severe delirium.
   Appreciate Neurology input who think he is encephalopathic and
   recommended MRI yesterday which is preliminarily negative.
   - F/u neuro recs
   - Tylenol first, then low dose fentanyl as needed for pain
   - Neuro recs if spikes new fever would need LP. Also watch for
   metabolic abnormalities, none apparent so far
   #) RUE swelling: ultrasound negative yesterday. Does have recent
   history of gout. Appear slightly improved.
   - Continue Prednisone 2.5mg PO qday
   - Consider pulling arterial line
   #) Tachycardia:  Unclear etiology.  EKGs consistent with sinus
   tachycardia with frequent PACs and PVCs. We are trying to control with
   metoprolol QID.
   - metoprolol 25 mg PO QID
   - increase as necessary
   #) Right wrist fracture: Now reduced and casted.  No plans for
   operative intervention.
   - orthopedics followup
   #) Dens Fracture:  [**Last Name (un) 10782**] Type II dens fracture.  Non-operative.
   Currently in [**Location (un) 2420**] J Collar.
   - continue collar.  Ask ortho how much longer that will be necessary.
   - will need orthopedics followup

   #) Chronic Kidney Disease: Baseline creatinine 1.4-1.6.  Currently
   improved to 1.1
   - renally dose medications
   - trend creatinine
   - goal today for I/Os is even to avoid further insult.
   #) Anemia: Baseline hematocrit in the high 30s, today 23.5.  Had large
   bleed several days ago from fem line site, none since.  Appears on labs
   to be anemia of chronic disease.
   - active type and screen
   - trend hematocrit with transfusion goal < 21
   #) Congestive Heart Failure: Concern for exacerbation of end stage
   diastolic heart failure complicated by severe AR and moderate MR in the
   setting of IV fluid resuscitation and holding home medications.
   - lasix 40 mg IV once, then follow-up
   - captopril 12.5mg TID and metoprolol 25mg QID
   - I/O goal
 even today

Summary:

The patient is a 89-year-old male admitted to the ICU with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), hypertension, chronic kidney disease, aortic insufficiency, and congestive heart failure. He was found down in his living room with odontoid and right wrist fractures, and was transferred to the ICU for hypoxic and hypercarbic respiratory failure. The patient is currently stable from a respiratory standpoint, but has persistent altered mental status, difficulty clearing secretions, and right hand swelling.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's primary problem is his difficulty clearing secretions, which can lead to further respiratory failure.
2. Delirium: The patient's altered mental status is a concern, and further evaluation by neurology is recommended.
3. Tachycardia: The patient's tachycardia is unclear in etiology and may be related to his underlying medical conditions.
4. Right Wrist Fracture: The patient has a right wrist fracture that is currently reduced and casted, and may require further orthopedic follow-up.
5. Dens Fracture: The patient has a dens fracture that is being managed with a collar, and may require further orthopedic follow-up.
6. Chronic Kidney Disease: The patient's chronic kidney disease is being managed with renally dosed medications, and his creatinine level is currently improving.
7. Anemia: The patient has anemia of chronic disease, and may require further evaluation and management.
8. Congestive Heart Failure: The patient has a history of congestive heart failure and may be at risk for exacerbation.
9. Gout: The patient has a history of gout and may require further evaluation and management.

Lab Results:

* WBC: 14.3
* Hct: 25.5
* Plt: 265 K/uL
* Cr: 1.1
* TCO2: 34
* Glucose: 141
* Other labs: Differential-Neuts: 89.6%, Band: 0.0%, Lymph: 4.6%, Mono: 5.6%, Eos: 0.2%, Lactic Acid: 1.3 mmol/L, LDH: 196 IU/L, Ca++: 7.9 mg/dL, Mg++: 2.2 mg/dL, PO4: 3.0 mg/dL

Imaging:

* MRI head without contrast: Preliminarily negative
* RUE u/s: No DVT
* CXR: Increased left pleural effusion and retrocardiac opacity, with a clear right lung.

Medications:

* Ceftriaxone: 1 gm Q24
* Azithromycin: 500mg Q24
* Metoprolol: 25 mg PO QID
* Captopril: 12.5mg TID
* Lasix: 40 mg IV once
* Albuterol and ipratropium nebulizers: Standing
* Prednisone: 2.5mg PO qday
* Fentanyl: As needed for pain
* Tylenol: As needed for pain
* Subutaneous heparin: Prophylaxis
* Pneumonia boots: Prophylaxis
* Pepcid: Prophylaxis

ICU Care:

* Nutrition: Fibersource HN (Full) - 60 mL/hour
* Glycemic Control: Not specified
* Lines: Arterial Line, PICC Line
* Prophylaxis: DVT, Stress ulcer, VAP
* Comments: Communication with son and other healthcare providers is important for patient care.

   Assessment and Plan: 89 year old male with a history of COPD,
   hypertension, chronic kidney disease, aortic insufficiency and
   congestive heart failure who was found down in his living [**Apartment Address(1) **] days
   prior to admission.  Here he was found to have odontoid and right wrist
   fractures, transferred from TSICU for hypoxic and hypercarbic
   respiratory failure.  Here he is stable from respiratory standpoint but
   active issues are now persistently altered mental status, difficulty
   clearing secretions, R hand swelling.
   #) Hypoxic and Hypercarbic Respiratory Failure:  Initially caused by
   acute on chronic heart failure worsened by hypertension and
   tachycardia, though now his primary problem is his difficulty clearing
   secretions.  While his O2 sats are generally in the mid to high 90s, he
   has periodic drops to the 80s and is therefore being kept on 30% FiO2
   with shovel mask.  He is still requiring Q3hr or more frequent
   suctioning.  Switched from levofloxacin to azithro/ceftriaxone out of
   fear of worsening mental status, now day 3 of 7 days.  No organisms on
   sputum.
   - ceftriaxone 1 gm Q24, azithromycin 500mg Q24 today day 3 of 7.
   - goal fluid balance even today.  Hold on giving Lasix this am though
   and f/u UOP later today
   - keep metoprolol at 25 mg PO QID and continue captopril 12.5mg TID to
   reduce afterload.
   - continue albuterol and ipratropium nebulizers
   - titrate O2 as needed to maintain sats.
   - continue frequent suctioning to clear secretions
 will need to touch
   base with family re: putting a trach in
   #) Delerium: He continues to wax and wane quite a bit.  He is able to
   communicate with his sons and they think he has improved, when we speak
   to him he doesn
t open his eyes and withdraws from noxious stimuli. We
   have not found a clear infectious source, though ICU admission alone in
   a man with baseline dementia could explain his severe delirium.
   Appreciate Neurology input who think he is encephalopathic and
   recommended MRI yesterday which is preliminarily negative.
   - Start standing Tylenol instead of prn to control his pain
   - F/u neuro recs
   - Neuro recs if spikes new fever would need LP. Also watch for
   metabolic abnormalities, none apparent so far.
   #) RUE swelling: ultrasound negative yesterday. Does have recent
   history of gout. Appear slightly improved.
   - Continue Prednisone 2.5mg PO qday
   - Pulling arterial line today
   - Plain film of R hand
   #) Tachycardia:  Unclear etiology.  EKGs consistent with sinus
   tachycardia with frequent PACs and PVCs. We are trying to control with
   metoprolol QID.
   - Will increase Metoprolol 25 mg PO QID  to 37.5 QID
